title: Meta: Reviving archived threads on this forum
content:
"This thread was archived. Please ask a new question if you need help."

I get it, but also, search engines mean that people will be directed to these posts, and they may be out of date.

Proposal: either add the ability to revive archived posts fully (when needed), or add the ability to add a "a related question was asked more recently: LINK" banner to old posts.

My personal example: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1226175 The core answer ("Type about:config" etc) still works but the additional note is no longer relevent (there is no "little i in a circle at the left end of the address bar" and I am assuming that there _was_ in a previous version of Firefox)

title: a simple way to remove all Firefox bookmark files
content:
When setting up a new, replacement PC, I only had an exported bookmarks.html that had *multiples* of my extensive collection of folders, subfolders, etc. Ugh. I found a very useful and effective app that did remove all those duplicated Folders and Bookmarks, however, it (or I) managed to put them completely out of order. That's the context of for this question-as-suggestion. I'm rebuilding my bookmarks.html now, using NotePad++ to edit and restore it to its previous state (Bookmarks Menu / folders / sub-folders / bookmarks). I check my work, as I continue to rebuild this bookmarks.html, by re-Importing it. The problem is that re-Importing the file merely*appends* it to the current contents, rather than replacing them. Here's the workaround I found to initialize my Firefox bookmarks configuration. In your Firefox Profiles folder (e.g.) C:\Users\YourUsername\AppData\Roaming\Mozilla\Firefox\Profiles\blahblah.default-release delete: 

- places.sqlite and  - content-prefs.sqlite

and also delete all contents in the /bookmarksbackup folder. By doing this, now when you "Import bookmarks from HTML...", it will contain only what was in your source file. I have the current version of Firefox as of this date, 115.0.2 (64-bit). I haven't noticed any problems using this workaround.

What can be done? I've been using FF for the past 20 years and support Mozilla w regular $$. I've tried clearing the cache, allowing pop-ups for their site, and I use no Extensions or Add-ons. Help! Windows 10, latest updates, FF 115.0.2

title: Website load times
content:
I did a clean install of both Firefox, which I have used for years, and Ghostery private browser, which I just heard about last week. I have used the Ghostery extension, in Firefox, for years also.

My homepage, in both, is Breitbart News. Whenever I use Firefox, it takes over 35 seconds to load Breitbart upon startup. Whenever I use Ghostery Private Browser, it takes less than 5 second to load Breitbart. The difference appears to be that Ghostery, obviously, is not an extension in Ghostery Private Browser!

The only difference I have noticed, so far, is that, in Ghostery PB, whenever I click on a Bookmark, it automatically opens up a new tab, while, in Firefox, the bookmark opens in the tab I'm in at the time.

SO, I have a few questions. Since Ghostery PB seems to be Firefox, is it really Firefox Light? That is, are there functions, in Firefox, that I don't have in Ghostery PB?

Then, if so, are there any settings, in Ghostery, that would remove 'Light' functionality or features and make both Firefox, with Ghostery extension, exactly the same as Ghostery PB!

And if that's the case, that there is no diffence, I might suggest that Ghostery be an option, on Firefox install, rather than a separate installation.

title: CSP strikes again
content:
CSP strikes again,

This morning I was trying to look at archive.org and the website wouldn't load and just show a blank white page (not my blank page theme which is dark)

I tried refreshing a few times, and it didn't work, then I opened developer tools and noticed every resource from website is blocked by CSP. I know probably this is a wrong configuration from archive.org developers causing the page to not load.

GET archive.org HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: nginx/1.18.0 (Ubuntu) Date: Tue, 18 Jul 2023 03:36:25 GMT Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8 Transfer-Encoding: chunked Connection: keep-alive vary: Accept-Encoding content-security-policy: base-uri 'self'; default-src *; img-src *; object-src 'none'; script-src https://archive.org/offshoot_assets/ https://*.archive.org/offshoot_assets/ https://offshoot.prod.archive.org/offshoot_assets/ https://archive.org/includes/ https://*.archive.org/includes/ https://offshoot.prod.archive.org/includes/ https://archive.org/components/ https://*.archive.org/components/ https://offshoot.prod.archive.org/components/ https://archive.org/jw/ https://*.archive.org/jw/ https://offshoot.prod.archive.org/jw/ https://av.prod.archive.org/js/ https://esm.archive.org/ https://polyfill.archive.org/v3/polyfill.min.js 'sha256-CoX53XgCdkM1zegYEEpMUeYIZnv663inNm8bQv2VRbM='; style-src 'unsafe-inline' https://archive.org/ https://*.archive.org/ https://offshoot.prod.archive.org/; Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=15724800 Expires: Tue, 18 Jul 2023 03:51:25 GMT Cache-Control: max-age=900 Referrer-Policy: no-referrer-when-downgrade X-Content-Encoding-Over-Network: gzip

from start CSP bring nothing for me other than trouble. In fact I had so much trouble with it, that when a website doesn't load or loads incomplete, I immediately hit F12 to see if anything is blocked by CSP.

I know some very knowledgeable people will come and tell me you will die instantly or will turn to stone if you disable CSP, but I'm readly fed up with this thing that is controled by a header that can be changed with a proxy or even extension which then controls how browser will load a website. just the same way that some web developers use User-agent and HTTP-Referer as a security measure in their website.

I was able to disable CSP in firefox 98 and browse the website. but can't do it with firefox 100 and above (109 currently)

I tried removing the CSP header with extension, but I can remove any header I want but not CSP

Apparently someone in firefox team is obsessed with removing user modifiable features and making it harder and harder everyday to achieve the same functionality (e.g. renaming about:config settings, disabling or removing them) or in other words, pushing their will on their end users on how they should use their browser.

I'm a software developer, I can recompile firefox, and I want CSP and in fact any behavior that relies on a HTTP-header to be gone, but I'm really busy with my own work. and don't have time to read through entire code of the firefox.

I would like to ask if someone can direct me to the part of mozilla code that contains CSP so I can remove it and compile the thing again so I have a browser that doesn't block me from what I like to do.
